statement.p:
Let a x'' + b x' + cx = 0, where a \neq 0 and b^2 - 4ac = 0.
Show that x_1(t) = e^{-bt/2a} is a solution to a x'' + b x' + cx = 0.
Assume that y = v(t) x_1(t) = v(t) e^{-bt/2a} is a solution to a x'' + b x' + cx = 0 and show that v(t) = c_1 + c_2 t. Thus, x(t) = c_1 e^{-bt/2a} + c_2 t e^{-bt/2a} is a general solution for a x'' + b x' + cx = 0.

ol.li:
Observe that
a x_1'' + b_1' + cx_1 & = a \left(\frac{-b}{2a}\right)^2e^{-bt/2a} + b \left( \frac{-b}{2a} \right) e^{-bt/2a} + c e^{-bt/2a} & = e^{-bt/2a} \left( \frac{b^2}{4a} - \frac{b^2}{2a} + c \right) & = e^{-bt/2a} \left( \frac{-b^2 + 4ac}{4a} \right) & = 0.

If y = v(t) x_1(t) = v(t) e^{-bt/2a} is a solution to our differential equation, then
a y'' + b y' + cy & = a (v''x_1 + 2 v'x_1' + vx_1'' ) + b(v' x_1 + v x_1') + cv x_1 & = a v''x_1 + 2a v'x_1' + bv' x_1 + v(a x_1'' +b x_1' + c x_1) & = a v'' e^{-bt/2a} + \left[2a \left( \frac{-b}{2a} \right) e^{-bt/2a} + b e^{-bt/2a} \right] v' & = a v'' e^{-bt/2a} & = 0.
Since a \neq 0, we know that v'' = 0. Hence, v(t) = c_1 + c_2 t.

statement.p:
Reduction of Order. Suppose that x_1(t) is a solution (not identically zero) to the equation x'' + p(t) x' + q(t) x = 0.
Assume that x(t) = v(t) x_1(t) is a solution to x'' + p(t) x' + q(t) x = 0 and derive the equation x_1 v'' +(2x_1' + px_1)v' = 0.
Let u = v' and show that is a first-order linear differential equation in u.
Show that x_1(t) = 1/t is a solution to 2 t^2 x'' + 3t x' - x = 0 for t \gt 0 and find a second linearly independent solution to .

ol.li: If u = v', then x_1 u' +(2x_1' + px_1)u= 0.

If x_1(t) = 1/t, then 2 t^2 x_1'' + 3t x_1' - x_1 = 2 t^2 \left(\frac{2}{t^3}\right) + 3t \left(\frac{-1}{t^2}\right) - \frac{1}{t} = 0. If we assume that x = v/t is a second solution, then 2 t^2 x'' + 3t x' - x = 2tv'' - v' = 0. If we let u = v', then a solution of 2tu' - u = 0 is u = \sqrt{t} and v = \int \sqrt{t} \, dt = 2 t^{3/2} / 3. Therefore, the second solution to our equation is x = \frac{v}{t} = \frac{2}{3} \sqrt{t}.
